context.item: You will analyze various types of publications to identify and extract specific, atomic elements such as citations, references, captions, and other small-scale components.
These elements are crucial for understanding the structure and academic rigor of publications across different fields and styles.
Pay close attention to the formatting and placement of these elements, as they often follow specific style guides (e.g., APA, MLA, Chicago).
Your analysis should cover both in-text elements (like inline citations) and standalone elements (like figure captions or bibliographic entries).
Be prepared to encounter variations in element styles across different types of publications (e.g., journal articles, books, reports).
When identifying elements, refer to the definitions provided in the XML tags.
Use the format specifications in the XML tags to structure your responses.
If you're unsure about an element's classification or format, refer to the guidance in the XML tags.
Pay attention to the document's structure, including sections, subsections, and various levels of headings.
Be aware of structural elements such as the table of contents, abstract, and keywords, which provide important context for the document's organization and content.
